 1. COUNTRY BACKGROUND 1.1 Angola is an undeveloped but potentially wealthy country in Southem Africa. Yet despite vast resources of oil, diamonds, rivers, coast and arable land, in 1994 the country's GDP was estimated at US$420 per capita. The Angolan population, 10.9 million' in 1993, has suffered from three consecutive decades of warfare. The war for independence from 1961 to 1974 provoked the abrupt exodus of 300,000 Portuguese in 1974 draining the country of virtually all skills and professions. The first civil war period was from 1976 to 1991, the second from 1992. The peace process, now underway, was initiated with the signing of the Lusaka Peace Accords, in November 1994. There is cautious optimism that peace will continue to hold. On August 11, 1995, the UNITA leader, Mr. Savimbi, accepted the Government's invitation to become one of the country's tWo vice-presidents. On the military front, demobilization is to proceed in three phases: (a) quartering of UNITA troops; (b) integration into a unified army; and (c) demobilization and reintegration. Donor financing is sought for the demobilization process, which the UN estimates to last 24 months and to cost US$103 million. 1.2 In the interim, social and economic infrastructure has deteriorated or been destroyed.. Despite massive emergency relief operations by Government and donor agencies, malnutrition and food insecurity are chronic. The economic impact of the war is reflected in the GDP's decline of 23 percent in real terms from 1992 to 1993. The oil sector, responsible for 87.6 percent of Government revenues, was unable to maintain previous production levels because facilities had been destroyed. As the population fled rural areas, subsistence agriculture collapsed and markets ceased to function. Lack of monetary constraint and fiscal contraction allowed annual inflation to reach 1838 percent in 1993. The balance of payments deteriorated by 32 percent between 1991 and 1992: in 1993 the budget deficit stood at about 23 percent of GDP. 1.3 Per capita GNP2 for 1994 was estimated at US$250. Income distribution in Angola is extremely skewed: a small group possess specialized but scarce skills: well-placed people in the oil and military sectors enjoy high living standards. At the same time, well over half the Angolan population falls below the poverty line (defined as the ability to buy a basic food basket or having an income below one-third of the mean).3 Many of those working in the informal sector are women who are constantly on the brink of disaster. 1.4 Population growth of 2.8 percent annually conceals the wide disparity between the country's rapid urban growth rate (7.5 percent annually from 1980-89) and slower growth in rural areas (0.3 percent for the same period). The urban population was estimated to be 42 percent of the total population in 1993. It is likely that this percentage continued to grow during 1994. Luanda alone is reported to hold one-fourth of the total population. The united nations estimates that over 2 million people are now returming to the country (former refugees), or moving to cities in search of work. Many of the urban poor live in squatter settlements without security of tenure. 1.5 Poverty in rural areas increases in direct proportion to the population's distance from markets and major roads. Over 90 percent of the rural population is engaged in subsistence farming and depends on marketing for cash income. Their livelihood in particular (and the rural economy in general) would be substantially improved by better access to credit, markets, information, and basic services (health, education, water, transport and sanitation) -- all severely constrained at present. 1.6 Between 9 and 20 million land mines need to be cleared before economic and social activities can be normalized. De-mining activities are being coordinated by the Mine Coordination Office in UCAH (Coordination Unit for Humanitarian Aid, a UN body). The UN is allocating US$11 million to cover the costs of establishing an institute, and training and equipping 24 teams (720 persons) of Angolan "de-miners". Of these funds, $6 million have been allocated for the de- mining of some 7,000 km of roads by a private South-African company. However, the costs of de- mining are expected to be substantial and only a small portion is covered by the UN assessed budget (not yet released). 1.7 Political stabilization and economic and social development are the Government's main goals. The Government recognizes that the large macroeconomic imbalances, the structural distortions, the high levels of poverty, and the disruption in basic services pose formidable obstacles to economic growth and peace consolidation. A comprehensive strategy for medium-term economic and social development and reform over the next three years is being prepared. A. Social Sectors and Services 1.8 With the coming of peace, the Government of Angola faces many new challenges. Although the State has been the sole provider of social services since independence, private health clinics, pharmacies and schools have opened in the past three years, and churches are slowly reclaiming their institutions which used to offer a range of social services. Lack of regulation has, however, led to many unlicensed practices, particularly in pharmaceutical and medical services. As a first step towards the development of private initiatives in social services, the Government intends to monitor living conditions and poverty. NGOs and intemational aid agencies, who have bocome the dominant providers of emergency food aid and medical care, are now being encouraged to reorient resources towards rehabilitation and development. 1.9 Government expenditures in the social sectors have declined sharply since 1992, as military expenditures have consumed an ever-increasing share of revenues. Spiraling inflation rates have so eroded Govemment salaries4 that many civil servants have abandoned their posts or have resorted to more lucrative activities. Provincial govemments have most of the administrative authority in the social sectors; the transfers they receive from the central Govermment are inadequate and provincial govemments have no legal authority to generate tax revenue. Some revenue from duties and stamp fees is channeled to the social sectors, especially to health services, but this comes nowhere near the resource level required. 4 High inflation rate (1,838 percent in 1993 and 972 percent in 1994) and highly fluctuating multiple exchange rates make analysis difficult.

Life expectancy at birth is among the lowest in Africa at 45 years. The high total fertility rate, estimated at 6.5 in 1990, contributes to poor matemal and child health care.5 In 1993, under-five mortality was estimated to be 320 per thousand and infant mortality: 195 per thousand live births. Measles, diarrhea and malaria -- all preventable and treatable -- are the leading causes of morbidity and mortality. Tuberculosis is a resurgent problem, exacerbated by AIDS. 1.11 Many health facilities, especially in rural areas, were destroyed by the war. Despite the scarcity of medicine and the dilapidated infrastructure, public facilities remain the principal source of health care for most people. Most facilities were built in the 1960s and 1970s, and need replacement or substantial renovation. This has not been sufficient to retain health professionals; between 1991 and 1993 the number of Angolan doctors in the public sector decreased from 662 to 630; the number of nurses decreased from 9,145 to 5,780 (39 percent). Some doctors may have moved to private sector practice. Some nurses may have left the profession or moved to the private sector. This represents a significant improvement since independence, when only 12 percent of the population was considered literate. In recent years, as both students and teachers fled rural areas, the primary school net enrollment rate has dropped to 50 percent.6 Secondary school education is underfunded and the enrollment rate is calculated to be 12 percent. 1.13 Many schools (especially in rural areas) were closed or destroyed by the war; the remaining few are severely overcrowded (in Luanda classroom size averages 140 students) and many schools are forced to operate on a three-shift system to accommodate the overflow of students. The quality of both urban and rural primary education suffers from deteriorating facilities, where poorly-trained teachers are often demoralized by the lack of equipment and books. 1.14 The national budget allocation for education was slashed from 18 percent in 1991 to 6 percent in 1994. Efforts have been made to mobilize altemative sources for sector-specific training (for example, a petroleum tax for training in the petroleum sector), but in general, there is neither a policy framework to promote private financing, nor cost recovery for either general or technical education. Water and Sanitation 1.15 Only 30 percent of the population, primarily in urban areas, has access to safe water, and even this access is sporadic. Water supply in Luanda is subject to frequent interruptions and fecal contamination. Since many urban settlements are unplanned, the local authorities are unable to provide essential services. The increasing volume of garbage dumped in residential areas and inadequate sanitation and waste disposal facilities in urban areas are leading to increasing outbreaks of disease and pollution. The incidence of water-borne diseases, including cholera in recent years, is high in rural areas where the destruction of water pumps and wells during the war virtually ended the supply of safe water. This has particularly affected women and children, who must walk long distances to fetch water for daily needs. The services offered at health facilities and schools are limited by inadequate water and sanitation facilities.  1.17 Poverty and food availability are directly correlated to the economic infrastructure and to the accessibility of and distance to markets and urban centers. In war-tom Angola, markets have been destroyed, storage facilities are in short supply, and access to both is complicated by poor road conditions.8 Food availability is limited seasonally, especially when the roads become impassable because of heavy rains. Local authorities have not been able to maintain rural roads because of lack of security, operating funds and equipment. In urban areas, road conditions make public transport scarce or expensive, further constraining economic activity. 1.18 The capacity for local food production has been devastated, and output has steadily declined, from 100 kg/capita of grain-equivalent in 1980 to an estimated 67 kg/capita in September 1993. This is an average of less than 600 calories per person per day, compared to the 2,100 calories required for the average adult. Large areas of fertile land lie fallow because of uncleared land mines. Crop yields could be substantially increased through the use of fertilizer and pesticides, rehabilitation and construction of irrigation channels and de-mining. Most of Angola's large agro-industrial processing plants are closed or destroyed, forcing the population to depend on imported, processed food. Each provincial govemor may have a lump-surn budget to import food to be distributed to social institutions, including cafeterias, orphanages, schools, and hospitals, but budgets are tragically insufficient. Private traders no longer have the foreign currency to import food, and the private sector is struggling to reactivate food supply, processing and distribution. Country Assistance Strategy and Past Involvement 1.19 Angola joined the World Bank Group in 1989. In 1991, the Bank responded promptly to the first peace process and to the Govemment's initial reform efforts by stepping-up lending to help strengthen institutional capacity and rebuild human and physical capital. Eight IDA credits to Angola in FY91-93 totaled about US$245 million. This IDA assistance program emphasized capacity building and preparation work for high-priority rehabilitation of physical and social infrastructure. The implementation of the Angola portfolio has been affected by the war, which broke out shortly after most such projects had been approved. This has required restructuring of some projects covering geographic areas which are not currently accessible. In some cases the result has been project designs which no longer correspond to changed post-war priorities. 1.20 The Bank assistance strategy in FY95 reflected a "low-case" scenario, with a minimum core lending program focusing on poverty alleviation, capacity building, and human resource development. The peace process, initiated in November 1994, appears to be gaining momentum as a result of the May and August 1995 meetings between President dos Santos and Mr. Savimbi. The economic reform process resumed in June 1995 with the virtual reunification of the official and parallel exchange rates and the 200-fold increase of oil product prices; it is now gaining speed and suggests strong commitment to comprehensive reforms. The recent Country Portfolio Performance Review (13-14 June, 1995) was a success. The Government manifested strong commitment to improve portfolio performance and prepared an Action Plan to achieve that objective. The Government's commitment and the cessation of hostilities are expected to lead to speedier implementation and greater focus on the policy reform aspects of operations. 1.21 Angola needs support in its triple transition from war to peace, from a centrally planned economy to a market-based economy, and from authoritarian to accountable governance. IDA's assistance strategy focuses on facilitating the transition to a peacetime economy by helping to rehabilitate devastated economic and social infrastructure, by supporting the process of economic 8 Land mines planted in dirt roads and around villages are another legacy of the wars.

Lessons Learned The Angola Social Action Fund (FAS): Lessons From the Pilot Experience 1.22 An IDA Project Preparation Facility advance (PPF) of US$2 million for the creation of a social fund to be executed by the Fundo de Apoio Social (FAS), was approved in 1993. The Angolan Government created the FAS, in October 1994, as an autonomous, decentralized agency to channel funds to communities. Administratively the FAS is headed by the National Board of Overseers (NBO) which sets policy. The National Coordination Unit (NCU), the central body, gives technical support, coordinates and supervises the activities of provincial offices, and manages the flow of funds between the Government and the provincial level. The provincial offices identify, approve and disburse the funds and supervise the community-based projects. The provincial offices are in close contact with the Provincial Board of Overseers. Currently the fund is fully established in four provincial offices: Benguela, Kwanza Sul, Namibe and Cabinda. 1.23 To date, 87 sub-projects have been approved, totaling US$1,656,000 equivalent. Eight sub-projects have been finalized and 31 are currently being executed. Disbursement for sub- project implementation totals about US$400,000 equivalent, averaging US$30,000 per month per province. Approximately 120 additional sub-projects are in the preparation pipeline. Thus far, these are largely for schools, health posts and water supply (including water supply for cattle). 1.24 The pilot experience has permitted testing and improvement of procuremnent and disbursement procedures; for example, simplified statements of expenditures (SOE) have been used since May, 1995. It has also provided indications of expected rates of sub-project implementation and FAS expansion to other provinces. During the pilot, the FAS has established transparent management systems and systems for sub-project identification, approval and supervision, as well as a computerized monitoring system at the provincial level to keep the NCU (and donors) informed on sub-project status. 1.25 The Social Fund was established first in the province of Kwanza Sul, which has a population of about 1 million people. It is an agricultural province which produces a significant surplus of food crops, as well as coffee and cotton. At the time that the FAS office was established, Kwanza Sul was divided by the war: the coastal areas were under the control of the Government. During the pilot period, the war ended and the inland areas, which had suffered substantial physical damage, became accessible to the FAS. 1.26 Initial community response to FAS in Kwanza Sul was very poor. Evaluation of the situation revealed the need to: (a) work with partners involved in community development activities, in particular NGOs and churches; (b) include in the FAS team personnel with the experience needed to design a social communication program; and,
 - 7 - (c) initiate information and social communication activities, even before opening a new provincial office. 1.27 At the early stages sub-project implementation was slow. The situation was evaluated and it was decided to: (a) assist communities to find technical solutions to their problems and work with NGOs to resolve implementation and management problems; (b) appraise projects carefully and withhold approval until all criteria are met; (c) seek back-up from the NCU when situations pass the competencies of the Provincial Offices; (d) analyze issues as soon as these arise and make decisions quickly; (e) share experience between provinces; (f) establish a routine for sub-project identification, approval and supervision so that decisions on project approvals can be taken quickly; and, (g) work closely with the Provincial Board of Overseers to establish the work program, especially where cooperation from government agencies or NGOs is needed. 1.28 The first months of decentralization showed lack of up-to-date information on sub-project implementation at the NCU and at donor level. Accordingly it was decided to: (a) set-up a Management and Monitoring Information System to provide weekly updates from the provinces to the NCU on a short computerized form; and (b) design a monthly summary of these reports, including an analysis of the situation, problem identification and actions taken (this monthly report is sent to IDA). 1.29 Most of the provinces faced problems such as shortage of construction materials, and the virtual absence of a banking system. The FAS has leamed to overcome these problems through: (a) working out creative banking solutions (including an IOU system with local wholesalers); (b) regular information-sharing on the availability of materials and the initiation of works from the provinces to Luanda and vice versa (and between provinces); and, (c) exploring altematives to traditional suppliers for scarce materials. 1.30 Technical evaluation of the first finished sub-projects suggest a low technical capacity to analyze architectural designs and to deal with procurement issues within the FAS provincial teams. As a result the FAS: (a) now includes one technical staff member with an engineering or architecture background in all provincial teams, (b) provides twice a year training in procurement and disbursement procedures and related issues during the life of the project; (c) operates a supervision schedule by which the specialist in procurement and architecture at the NCU visits the provinces; and, (d) ensures that provincial teams now discuss with communities ways to improve the quality of the proposals.

These have influenced the conceptual framework, design and implementation arrangements of the Angola FAS. During the preparation of the Project, the FAS team visited the Salvador and Bolivia Social Funds and later adapted some concepts to the Angolan context. Both visits were especially valuable because the team leamed about potential pitfalls at first hand. Objectives and Summary Description 2.1 The Social Action Project (SAP) aims to assist Angola in its transition from war to peace, targeting in particular the people impoverished by the military and economic crises. 2.2 Objectives. The objectives of the Project are to: (a) improve access to basic services through the provision or rehabilitation of community infrastructure; (b) improve the capacity of communities and NGOs to plan, appraise, manage and maintain investment activities, through experience gained in the Project; (c) generate additional income and employment in rural and urban areas through revenue- generating sub-projects; and, (d) enhance the capacity of Angolan institutions to collect and analyze poverty-related data; (e) provide a better understanding of the main causes of poverty in order to help formulate effective poverty alleviation strategies and generate adequate policies for socioeconomic development. 2.3 Summary of Project Description. To achieve these objectives the SAP will finance over a four-year period, operational costs, infrastructure rehabilitation and construction, equipment and vehicles, training activities, surveys and studies, for the following two components: (a) A Social Action Fund component executed by the Fundo de Apoio Social (fAS) (93 .5 percent of total project costs) which will finance sub-projects identified, prepared and implemented by local communities. These sub-projects will be appraised and supervised by the FAS; (b) A Poverty Monitoring component executed by the Gabinete de Monitorizaao da Condices de Vida da Populacao (GMCVP Office for Monitoring Living Conditions of the Population) of the National Statistics Institute (INE) (6.5 percent of total project cost). This component will finance policy-relevant research on poverty and social issues, and systematic poverty monitoring through household surveys. 2.4 Project Rationale. The greatest challenge facing the Government of Angola at present is to restore social confidence and promote the resumption of economic growth, with a sharp focus on poverty alleviation and job creation. A critical element in this program will be the provision of basic social and economic infrastructure throughout the country. 2.5 The Govenment has articulated a National Community Reconstruction Program aimed at restoring social services and security in peri-urban and rural areas. This project was presented at
 - 10- the Round Table in Brussels as one component of the National Program. Recognizing that addressing community needs was fundamental for the country's reconstruction and stability, even before the peace treaty was signed, Govenmment requested IDA's assistance to set up a project to support community-based rehabilitation of basic social, productive and economic infrastructure. Several alternatives were considered for the program. The Government realizes that although the existing structure is well-suited for serving the needs of the central urban areas, it may not be adequate to serve outlying urban or rural areas, and it may not incorporate community input to the extent necessary. One model considered was the semi-public procurement agency (known as Agence d 'Execution des Travaux d 'Interet Public or AGETIP in several African countries) where the focus is on ensuring the access of small contractors to the public investments. Currently this is not feasible in Angola as the contracting industry is in its infancy and is not geared towards labor- intensive implementation. This approach is difficult to reconcile with a full demand-driven approach needed to ensure the full participation of communities in identification and implementation of sub-projects. 2.6 The remaining option is the social investment fund model which has been successfully applied in several African and Latin American countries (including Zambia, Bolivia, Ethiopia and Honduras). Restoring self-confidence in communities and building community feeling is very important in Angola where the social fabric has been damaged by years of conflict. Social investment funds have proved to be both successful in encouraging commnunity participation and sufficiently flexible to meet community demand's at lower costs than Govenmment provision would entail. During the pilot phase, the average investment costs per square meter to rehabilitate primary schools was estimated at US$80; the cost to rehabilitate a primary school by the Government would average US$358 per square meter (see Annex 0). 2.7 On the basis of these considerations, Government decided to create a social fund. The Government proposed that 93.5 percent of the proceeds of the Credit be channeled through an autonomous decentralized agency, the FAS, under the Ministry of Planning. During its pilot phase, the FAS has proved its ability to react quickly and effectively to medt community demands. Being part of the local community, staff at the provincial level are readily accountable to the community and are immediately familiar with the most vulnerable and poor areas in their provinces. 2.8 Because poverty alleviation and human resource development are the most critical areas to be monitored, a second small component of the Project will begin to re-establish basic statistical capacity. Because of decades of war, Angola has virtually no capacity to conduct household and other national surveys and so cannot monitor changes in the extent and nature of poverty. 2.9 The current Project responds to Government's request for support by offering a streamlined and flexible approach to community needs for micro projects providing economic and social infrastructure, support for directly productive investment, and a Poverty Monitoring component that will strengthen the country's capacity to identify the needs of the population. The project is consistent with the Government's own development objectives and reflects the priorities of IDA's country assistance objectives, namely, poverty alleviation and human resource development.

Social Action Fund Component Creation and Strategy 2.10 The Angolan Govemment created the FAS10, by Decree No. 44/94 of October 5, 1994, and Executive Decree No. 2/94 of December 30, 1994, as an autonomous structure in order to have flexible funding, procurement and disbursement procedures and to avoid political interference. At negotiafions, agreement was reached with Government to establish a Subsidiary Grant Agreement between Govemment and the FAS, acceptable to IDA, which will govern the granting of the proceeds of IDA Credit to the FAS. Methodology: includes group class sessions with exercises, interview games and field sessions as direct practice exercises. After training interviewers will be selected, on the basis of regular tests and the trainers' appreciation of their personality and capacity. (b) Data Entry Clerks: data entry staff. The training will consist of a short version of training for the enumerators in addition to a program used for data entry and intensive practice so that data entry staff will acquire the necessary speed. Duration: two weeks. Methodology: classroom and computer laboratory sessions. After training, data entry clients will be selected according to their capacity to deliver timely and correct work. (c) Supervisors: the candidates will need previous survey experience or high level of education (usually a Master's degree). They will follow training sessions for
 -66 - Annex N enumerators and data entry clerks, complemented by training on organization of field work, management of the teams, supervision of interviews and verification of questionnaires. Duration: three weeks. Methodology: theoretical sessions and practice of supervision during the field exercises for the enumerators and verification of the outputs of the data entry clerks' exercises. Survey design and organization. Survey design and implementation: candidates (one or two per year) will attend the Abidjan training session organized by the World Bank and the Munich Training Center. During the project, the staff will visit countries where poverty-related surveys are implemented to expose the staff to problems encountered, new methods used and adaptations to specific issues. Two trips of 20 days duration have been budgeted. Qu:-litative techniques: organized for surveys such as beneficiary and participatory assessments. Methodology: direct TA, on-the-job training related to the study program delivered by experienced international consultants. Sampling techniques: on-the-job training will be organized either as a study trip or at a local workshop. The study trip will be organized with a foreign statistical office to complete the training of two persons in sampling techniques and by exposing them to the sampling design and execution of surveys already implemented. Any locally-held workshop will cover the same content, using the same or equivalent training methodology. Data Analysis Data analysis and processing: one study trip will be organized with SIIPCO, the US Census Bureau for IMPS (6 weeks). The objective is to improve and adapt the skills of one staff member to the processing and analysis of the poverty surveys. On-the-job training will be given, throughout the implementation of the survey program, with direct support provided to GMCVP for programming data entry and consistency checks and tabulation. Poverty data analysis and modeling: on-the-job training through direct TA. Targeted to all technical people working in survey design and implementation. This training will focus on macro modeling for the development of generalized equilibrium models and a social accounting matrix; poverty analysis from quantitative and qualitative surveys; weighting for price index; gender analysis; incomes and expenditure data preparation; classifying households, socioeconomic and target groups; employment and labor market; and the informal sector. Seminars and workshops on specific topics will be organized as necessary. Other Study Trips or training activities. The project will provides fund for staff to participate in international events organized by the donors on Poverty and Development issues related to analysis and research techniques. Appropriate training will be provided for the establishment at GMCVP of an integrated Management Information System.

doc.abstracts: The Social Action Project aims to assist Angola in its transition from war to peace, targeting in particular the people impoverished by the military and economic crises. The objectives of the project are to: 1) improve access to basic services through the provision or rehabilitation of community infrastructure; 2) improve the capacity of communities and nongovernmental organizations (NGOs) to plan, appraise, manage and maintain investment activities, through experience gained in the project; 3) generate additional income and employment in rural and urban areas through revenue-generating sub-projects; 4) enhance the capacity of Angolan institutions to collect and analyze poverty-related data; and 5) provide a better understanding of the main causes of poverty in order to help formulate effective poverty alleviation strategies and generate adequate policies for socioeconomic development. The project consists of the following two components: 1) a social action fund component which will finance sub-projects identified, prepared and implemented by local communities; and 2) a poverty monitoring component which will finance policy-relevant research on poverty and social issues, and systematic poverty monitoring through household surveys.
